titleStmt.title: Fourteene strange prophesies: besides Mother Shiptons, and Mr. Salmarsh, predicting wonderfull events to betide these yeares of calamity, in this climate, whereof divers are already come to passe, worthy of observation. 1. A prophesie of K. Richard the 3. 2. Mother Shiptons prophesie. 3. Mr. Truswels, recorder of Lincolne. 4. Sibyllaes prophesies. 5. Ignatius prophesie. 6. Merlins prophesie. 7. Orwel Bins prophesies. 8. Mr. Brightmans prophesies 6. [sic] Ancient prophesies in meeter. Whereto is added the predictions of Mr. John Saltmarch, to his Excellency, and the counsell of his army. And the manner of his death. Printed by an exact true copy, with new marginall notes on Mother Shiptons prophesies.

A prophesie of K. Richard the 3. 2. Mother Shiptons prophesie. 3. Mr. Truswels, recorder of Lincolne. 4. Sibyllaes prophesies. 5. Ignatius prophesie. 6. Merlins prophesie. 7. publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Richard Harper, at the Bible and Harpe in Smithfield,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Foureteene ≈øtrange PROPHESIES: Be≈øides Mother Shiptons, and Mr. Saltmar≈øh, predicting wonderfull events to betide the≈øe yeares of calamity, in this Climate, whereof divers are already come to pa≈ø≈øe, worthy of ob≈øervation.

list.item: 1. A Prophe≈øie of K. Richard the 3.

div.p: Whereto is added the Predictions of Mr. John Saltmarch, to his Excellency, and the Coun≈øell of his Army. And the manner of his Death.
Printed by an exact true copy; with new marginall Notes on Mother Shiptons Prophe≈øies.
Printed for Richard Harper, at the Bible and Harpe in Smi ‚Ä¢ hfield. 1648.

div.head: Mr. Saltmar≈øhes Predictions declared to his Excellency the Lord Fairfax, and the Coun≈øell of his Army; with the Motives that occa≈øioned it: and the manner of his Death.
div.p: HE being at his hou≈øe nere Y ‚Ä¢ lford in E≈ø≈øex, Decemb. 4. 1647. told his Wife, that he had received a command from God, to make knowne to the Army what the Lord had revealed unto him: The like he ≈øayd to Sir H. ‚Ä¢ Knight, a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, as ≈øoone as he arived at London. The next dy (being ‚Ä¢ he Lords day) he found ≈øome difficulty to procure a Hor≈øe, but after dinner he got one, and rid alone towards Wind≈øor. But mi≈ø≈øing his way, lodged at night 7. miles ≈øhort; where he declared, That the great and dreadfull Day of the Lord is neere, when all men ≈øhall be judged by Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and then ≈øhall the waies and actions of all men appeare, &c. Early the next day, Decemb. 6. he againe mi≈ø≈øed his way in a Forre≈øt, but e≈øpying a hou≈øe, rid to it to demand his way, and there made knowne, That God was purpo≈øed to de≈øtroy the wicked, and draw the Saints to him≈øelfe, with much more: after which he departed, and about nine of the clock came to Wind≈øor; where Mr. A. an Adjutator ≈øaluting him, he ≈øaid Mr. A. Depart from the≈øe Tents le≈øt you peri≈øh with them, for the Lord hath revealed unto me, that he is angry with this Army, becau≈øe they have for≈øaken him. Another, a Captaine asked him how he did? To whom he replyed, That he had nothing from God to ≈øay to him, becau≈øe he had alwais beene a ≈øeeker under ≈øpecious pretences. Then ≈øeeing one C. D. another Officer, he ≈øaid, he could not owne him, for he was for de≈øtruction. Then going to the Generall Councell, where many Officers were met in expectation of the Generall, he told them, That he was come thither to reveale the Lords command; That though God had done much for them, and by them, yet he had left them and their Councels, becau≈øe they had for≈øaken him: That God would not pro≈øper their Con≈øultations, but de≈øtroy them by divi≈øions among≈øt them≈øelves; That formerly he came like a Lambe, but now God had rai≈øed in him the ≈øpirit of a Lyon, becau≈øe they had ‚Ä¢ ought to de≈øtroy the people of God. Some ≈øaid that he lookt like one di≈øtracted, and that he had beene ≈øick, and was not well recovered; to whom he replyed, that he had beene ≈øick, but well in health then, and ≈øen≈øible of what he ≈øaid, and that ≈øhould be the la≈øt time that ever he ≈øhould ≈øpeake to them. Afterwards he went to the Generall, not moving his hat, and told him, That he had no command from God to honour him, That he had honoured him ≈øo much, as he offended God in doting on his per≈øon, and that God would no longer pro≈øper him, &c. Then going to the L. Gen. who asked him how he did? he (without any re≈øpect) an≈øwered him, That God was very angry with him for abu≈øing the godly, and that the Armies falling from their fir≈øt Principles, would occa≈øion their ruine and de≈øtruction, &c. After which he departed, and on Tue≈øday, Decemb. 7. went againe to the L. Gen. and declared, That he was ≈øorry to ≈øee ≈øuch ob≈øtinacy in him, and wi≈øhed him to be mindfull of what God had declared unto him: Afterwards he tooke his leave of the Army, and ≈øaid he had done his Errand, and mu≈øt leave them never to ≈øee the Army more. On Wedne≈øday, Decemb. 8. he came to London, and tooke leave of ≈øome friends, to whom he recommended his wife. On Thur≈øday Decemb. 9. he went from London to his hou≈øe at Y ‚Ä¢ lford, not ≈øick at all, and told his wife what he had done. On Fryday Decemb. 10, he ≈øaid he had fini≈øhed his cour≈øe, and mu≈øt go to his Father. In the afternoone he ≈øaid his head aked, and laid him≈øelfe upon his Bed. On Saturday, Decemb. 11. he was taken ≈øpeechle≈ø≈øe, and about four or five a clock that afternoone dyed.

div.head: A Prediction of King Richard the Third.
div.p: IN the Raigne of King Richard the third, his Maje≈øty with his Army lay at Leice≈øter the night Before the battle at Bo≈øworth field was fought. It happened in the Morning as the King rode through the South-gate, a poor old blind man (by profe≈ø≈øion a Wheel wright) ≈øat begging, and hearing of his approach ≈øaid, that if the Moone changed twice that day, having by her ordinary cour≈øe changed in the Morning, King Richard ≈øhould lo≈øe his Crowne, and be ≈ølaine; and riding over the bridge his left foot ≈øtruck again≈øt a ≈øtump of wood, which the old man hearing, ≈øaid, Even ≈øo ≈øhall his head at his returne back hit on the ≈øame place, which ≈øo came to pa≈ø≈øe: And a Nobleman that carried the Moone for his Colours, revolted from King Richard, whereby he lo≈øt that day his Life, Crowne, and Kingdome; which verified the Pre≈øages of that poore blinde old man.

div.head: The Prophe≈øie of Shiptons Wife in the time of King Henry the Eight.
div.p:
Note, that this Prophe≈øie was never exactly printed before.VVHen ≈øhe heard that King Henry the Eight ≈øhould be King, and Cardinall Wol≈øey ≈øhould be at Yorke, ≈øhe ≈øaid that Cardinall Wol≈øey ≈øhould never come to Yorke, which the King and the Cardinall hearing, being angry, ≈øent the Duke of Suffolke and the Lord Darcy to her, who came with their men di≈øgui≈øed to the Kings hou≈øe neare Yorke, where leaving their men they went to Mr. Be≈øly to Yorke, and de≈øired him to go with them to Mother Shiptons hou≈øe, where when they came they knocked at the doore, ≈øhe ≈øayd, come in Mr. Be≈øly, and tho≈øe honourable Lords with you, and Mr. Be≈øly would have put in the Lords before him; but ≈øhe ≈øayd, come in Mr. Be≈øly, you know the way, but they doe not. This they thought ≈øtrange that ≈øhe ≈øhould know
them, and never ≈øaw them; then they went into the hou≈øe, where there was a great fire, and ≈øhe bad them welcome, calling them all by their names, and ≈øent for ≈øome Cakes and Ale, and they dranke and were very merry. Mother Shipton, ≈øaid the Duke; if you knew what we came about, you would not bid us ≈øo welcome; ≈øhe ≈øaid the me≈ø≈øenger ≈øhould not be hanged: Mother Shipton, ≈øaid the Duke, you ≈øaid the Cardinall ≈øhould never ≈øee Yorke; yea ≈øaid ≈øhe, I ≈øayd he might ≈øee Yorke, but never come at it. But ≈øaid the Duke, when he comes to Yorke thou ≈øhalt be burned; we ≈øhall ≈øee that, ≈øaid ≈øhe, and plucking her hankercher off her head, ≈øhe threw it into the fire, and it would not burne: then ≈øhe tooke her ≈øtaffe and turned it into the fire, and it would not burne; then ≈øhe tooke it and put it on againe. Then ≈øaid the the Duke, what meane you by this? ≈øhe replyed, if this had burned, I might have burned. Mother Shipton, quoth the Duke, what thinke you of mee? My Lord, ≈øayd ≈øhe, the time will comeThe Duke was afterward beheaded. you will be as low as I am, and that is a low one indeed.

My Lord Piercy ≈øaid, and what ≈øay you of me? My Lord, ≈øaid ≈øhe, ≈øhooe your hor≈øe in the quick, and you will doe well, but yourThis proved true, for he ro≈øe in rebellion in the North, and by not flying when he might he was taken and beheaded at York, where his body was buried; but his head was ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ol ‚Ä¢ away and carried into France. te ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ Eliz, R. body will be buried in Yorke pavement, and your head ≈øhall be ≈øtolne from the Barre and carried into France: At which they all laughed, ≈øaying, that would be a great lop betweene the head and the body. Then ≈øaid the Lord Darcy, and what think you of me? She ≈øaid, you have made a great Gun, ≈øhoot it off, for it will never doe you no good; you are going to war, you will paine many a man, but kill none: So they went away.

Not long after the Cardinall came to Cawood, and going to the top of the Tower, He asked, where ≈øtands Yorke, and how far it was thither? and ≈øaid, that one ≈øaid he ≈øhould never ≈øee Yorke; nay, ≈øaid one, ≈øhe ≈øaid you might ≈øee Yorke, but never come at it. He vowed to burne her when he came to Yorke. Then they ≈øhewed him Yorke, and told him it was but eight miles thence; he ≈øaid that he would ≈øoone be there; but being ≈øent for by the King, he died in his way to London, at Leice≈øter of a laske. And Shiptons wife ≈øaid to Mr. Be≈øly, yonder is a fine ≈øtall built for the Cardinall in the Min≈øter, of gold, pearle; and precious ≈øtones, goe and pre≈øent one of the pillars to King Henry; and he did ≈øo.

Mr. Be≈øly ≈øeeing the≈øe things fall out as ≈øhe had foretold, de≈øired her to tell him ≈øome more of her Prophe≈øies. Mr. Be≈øly ≈øaid ≈øhe, before thatThis came to pa≈ø≈øe, for Trinity ≈øteeple in Yorke was blown downe with a tempe≈øt, and Ow≈øe Bridge was broken downe with a great floud; and what they did in repairing ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e bridge in the day time with the ≈øtone of the ≈øteeple, fell downe in the night, untill they (remembring thi ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ rophe≈øie) laid the highe≈øt ≈øtone of the ≈øteeple for the foundation of the bridge, and then the worke ≈øtood. And by this was partly verified another of Mother Shiptons Prophe≈øies (viz.) That her maid ≈øhould live to drive her Cow over Trinity ≈øteeple. Ow≈øe Bridge and Trinity Church meet, they ≈øhall build on the day, and it ≈øhall fall in the night, untill they get the highe≈øt ≈øtone of Trinity Church, to be the lowe≈øt ≈øtone of Ow≈øe Bridge.

Then the day will come when the North ≈øhall rue it wondrous ≈øore, but the South ≈øhall rue it for evermore; when hares kindle on cold hearthSuppo≈øed to be mean by ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of Abbien and other Religions hou≈øes. And at the Lord William Howards hou≈øe at Naworth, a Hare came and kindled in his Kitchen upon the hearth. ≈øtones, and lads ≈øhall marry Ladies and bring them home, then ≈øhall
you have a yeare of pining hunger, and then a dearth without come, a wofull day will be ≈øeene in England, a King and a Queene.

The fir≈øt comming of theThis was fulfilled in K. James his comming in, for ≈øuch a multitude of people ≈øtood at Holgate bar to behold him, as that to avoid the pre≈ø≈øe, he was forced to ride by another way. King of Scots ≈øhall be at Holgate Towne, but hee ≈øhall not come through the Bar, and when the KingWhen King James was at London, his children were at Edenborough, prepareing to come in to England. of the North ≈øhall be at London, his tayl ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall be at Edenborough.

After this ≈øhall waterThis is verified by the conducting of water into Yorke ≈øtreets through boared Elmes: And the Conduit hou≈øe hath a Windmill on the top that drawes up the water. come over Ow≈øe bridge, and a windmill ≈øhal be ≈øet on a tower; and an Elm-tree ≈øhall lye at every mans doore, at that time women ≈øhall weare great hats and great bands.
And when there is a Lord MajorA Lord Major who≈øe hou≈øe was in the Min≈øter yard in Yorke, was killed with three ≈øtabs. at Yorke, let him beware of a ≈øtabbe.

When two KnightsSir Tho. Wentworth & Sir John Savill in choo≈øing Knights for the Shire in the Ca≈øtle yard in Yorke, did ≈øo fall out, that they were never after well reconciled. ≈øhall fall out in the Ca≈øtle-yard, they ≈øhall never be kindly all their lives after.

When all ColtonColton hag in her rime was a Wood land ground full of trees, which bore corn ≈øeven yeers, and the ≈øeaventh yeer after that was the year of the comming in of the Scots, and their taking of Newca≈øtle. hag hath borne corps of Corne, ≈øeven yeares after you ≈øhall heare newes, there ≈øhall two JudgesIn the yeare 1616. two Judges of A≈ø≈øize went out at a gate in Yorke, where never any Judges were knowne to goe out before or ≈øince. goe in and out at Walmgate Bar.

l.hi: Then Wars ≈øhall begin in the Spring,

lg.l: Much woe to England it ≈øhall bring:

l.hi: Then ≈øhall the Ladies cry well away,
That ever we liv'd to ≈øee this day.

div.p: Then be≈øt for them that have the lea≈øt, and wor≈øt for them that have the mo≈øt: you ≈øhall not know of the warre over night, yet you ≈øhall have it in the morning: and when it comes it ≈øhall la≈øt three yeares: betweene Cardon and Aire ≈øhall be great warfare, when all the world is as lo≈øt, it ≈øhall be called Chri≈øts Cro≈øt. When the battell begins, it ≈øhall be whereNear Leice≈øter, where Richard the third was ≈ølaine in battell, the Collonell Ha≈øtings was one of the fir≈øt in Armes, endevouring to ≈øettle the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, in oppo≈øition to others that were then ≈øetling the Militia. Crook-back Richard made his fray.

They ≈øhall ≈øay, to warfare for your King for halfe a crowne a day, but ≈øtir not, (they will ≈øay) to warfare for your King on paine of hanging, but ≈øtirre not, for he that goes to complaine, ≈øhall not come backe againe.
The time will come when England ≈øhall tremble and quake for feare of a dead man that ≈øhall be heard to ≈øpeake: then will the Dragon give the Bull a great ≈ønap, and when the one is downe they will goe to London Towne: Then there will be a great battaile betweene England and Scotland, and they will be pacified for a time, and when they come to Brammamore they fight and are againe pacified for a time, then there will be a great battell between England and Scotland at Stockmore: Then will Ravens ≈øit on theIt is to be noted and admited, that this Cro≈ø≈øe in the North in Mother Shiptons dayes was a tall ≈øtone Cro≈ø≈øe, which ever ≈øince hath been by degrees ≈øinking into the ground, and now is ≈øunke ≈øo low, that a Raven may ≈øit upon the top of it, and reach her bill to the ground. Cro≈ø≈øe, and drink as much bloud of Nobles as of the Commons, then woe is me, for London ≈øhall bee de≈øtroyed for ever after.

There will come a woman with one eye, and ≈øhe ≈øhall tread in many mens bloud to the knee, and a man leaning on a ≈øtaffe by her, ≈øhe ≈øhall ≈øay to him, what art thou? and he ≈øhall ≈øay, I am the King of Scots, and ≈øhe ≈øhall ≈øay, goe with me to my hou≈øe, for there are three Knights, and hee will goe with her, and ≈øtay there three dayes and three nights, then will England be lo≈øt, and they will cry twice a day, England is lo≈øt. Then there will be three Knights in Peter-gate in York, and the one ≈øhall not know of the other; there ≈øhall be a childe borne in Pomfret with three thumbs, and tho≈øe three Knights will give him three hor≈øesThere is a childe not many yeares ≈øince borne at Pomfret with three thumbs. to hold while they winne England, and all Noble bloud ≈øhall be gone but one; and they ≈øhall carry him to Sheriffe Huttons Ca≈øtle ≈øixe miles from York, and he ≈øhall dye there, and they ≈øhall chu≈øe there an Earle in the Field, and hanging their hor≈øes on a thorne, and rue the time that ever they were borne to ≈øee ≈øo much bloud ≈øhed. Then they will come to Yorke to be≈øiege it, and they ≈øhall keep them out three dayes and three nights, and a penny loafe ≈øhall be within the Bar at halfe a Crowne, and without the Bar at a penny; and they will ≈øweare if they will not yeild, to blow up the Towne walls: Then they will let them in, and they will hang up the Major, Sheriffes and Aldermen, and they will goe into Crouch Church, there will three Knights goe in, and but one come out againe, and he will cau≈øe Proclamation to be made, that any man may take hou≈øe, towre, or bower for 21. yeares, and whil≈øt the world endureth, there ≈øhall never be warfare againe, nor any more Kings or Queenes, but the Kingdome ≈øhall bee governed by three Lords, and then Yorke ≈øhall bee London. And after this ≈øhall be a white harve≈øt of Corne gotten in by women. Then ≈øhall be in the North, that one woman ≈øhall ≈øay unto another, Mother, I have ≈øeene a man to day, and for one man there ≈øhall be a thou≈øand women: there ≈øhal bee a man ≈øitting on St. Ia ‚Ä¢ es Church hill
weeping his fill: And after that a Ship came ≈øailing up the Thames till it came again≈øt London, and the Mr. of the Ship ≈øhall weepe, and the Marriners ≈øhall aske him why he weepeth, being he hath made ≈øo good a voyage, and he ≈øhall ≈øay; Ah what a goodly City this was, none in the world comparable to it, and now there is le ‚Ä¢ t ≈øcare any hou≈øe that can let us have drinke for our money.

l.hi: Vnhappy he that lives to ≈øee the≈øe dayes,

lg.l: But happy are the dead Shiptons wife ≈øayes.

l.hi: In the worlds old age this woman did foretell,
Strange things ≈øhould hap which in our times have fell.

div.head: Mr. Tru≈øwels, Recorder of Lincolne.
div.p: THe Lilly ≈øhall remaine in a merty world, and he ≈øhall be moved again≈øt the ≈øeed of the Lyon, and he ≈øhall ≈øtand on one ≈øide among≈øt thrones of his Kingdome and Countrey: and there ≈øhall come the Son of man beating three wild bea≈øts in his Armes, which Kingdome is the Land of the Moone, which is to be dread throughout all the world, with a company of people he ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe many waters, and he ≈øhall come to the Land of the Lyon, looking for helpe, with the bea≈øts of his owne Countrey: And in that yeere there ≈øhall come an Eagle out of the Ba≈øt, and his wings ≈øpread with the beames of the Sonne of man: And that yeere ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed Ca≈øtles upon Thames, and there ≈øhall be great feare over the whole world; and in a part of the Land there ≈øhall be great battells among≈øt many Kingdomes: That day ≈øhall be the bloody field, and the Lilly ≈øhall lo≈øe his Crowne, and therewith ≈øhall be crowned the Sonne of man. And in the fourth yeere, many battells ≈øhall be for the Faith, and mo≈øt of the world ≈øhall be ≈øtoopen, but the Sonne of man with the Eagle ≈øhall be preferred, and there ≈øhall be univer≈øall peace over the whole world: Then ≈øhall the Son of man receive a marvellous token, and there ≈øhall be great plenty of all manner of fruits, and then ≈øhall he goe to the land of the cro≈ø≈øe.

div.head: The Prophe≈øie of old Sybilla.
div.l: VVHen Scotland hundred and ninth unconquered King,
The ≈øixteenth hundred thirty and ninth yeere,
Into his age of thirty nine ≈øhall reigne,
Then ≈øhall the Papall overthrow appeare,
Which all the Arts of Europe ≈øhall admire:
For Scotland ≈øhall that ble≈ø≈øed worke begin,
Then ≈øhall the whore of Babel we had here,
Be bani≈øht quite which Bi≈øhops did bring in.
Then thou brave England, which wa≈øt led ≈øo blinde
By their perver≈øe Epi≈øcopall pride,
And Irelands ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe ≈øuper≈øtitious ≈øin
Shall be ≈øuppre≈øt, who cruelly have cried;
So that, that Sacred Prophete≈ø≈øe Sybilla,

div.head: Merlins Prophe≈øies.

That Lincolne was, that London is, that York ≈øhall b ‚Ä¢
Brave London prayes tho≈øe dayes ≈øhe ne're may ≈øee.

Of grace and beauty ≈øome ≈øhall lurch;

The Adamant of Subjects love:

And lop a head off on a block:

And women be allowed to teach;

Of Religion, while they it toffe

Of plenty and growes proud of goods,

There ≈øhall be a dolefull tragedy:
The Lord abroad his ≈øword will ≈øend,

Yet Germany, France and Brkeny,
This la≈øt act of my tragedy.
Good dayes will follow, bad ones ce ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ,
There ≈øhall be plenty and great pence:
The whore of Romes no≈øe ≈øhall be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t,
And of her rich attire be ≈øtript:
In the meane time Bi≈øhops ≈øhall be
Throwne downe from all their dignity ‚Ä¢
Their Hierarchy and their traine
Shall ne're recover ≈øtrength againe:
Nor is Romes City only Rome,
But all the Popes dominion;
So that Rome feels her annoy'd,
While ≈øhe in Ireland is de≈øtroy'd:
In forty one by computation,
The Pope ≈øhall fall by Reformation:
A Clergy man ≈øhall then ≈øuffice,
His pride with one poore Benefice ‚Ä¢
Then Cambridge and the Oxonian
Shall be ≈øcorn'd by the Rotundian,
And ≈øome that cannot ≈øay nor ≈øing,

And Coblers then ≈øhall leave their la≈øt;
In Sermons up their gall to ca≈øt:

Both of the Aegle and the State,
Untill they bring things in conclu≈øion,
To much di≈øorder and confu≈øion.
Rebels and men mo≈øt ≈øeditious,
Shall make the time prove pernicious.
Rich men ≈øhall doe things unbefitting,
An upright Judge be ≈øcarce found ≈øitting;
Up≈øtart honour ≈øhall prove dreames;
And Bi≈øhops Seas prove little ≈øtreames:
While many a feather'd fowle ≈øhall fli ‚Ä¢ .
Beyond the Seas for jeopardy;

Shall pull the Cro≈ø≈øe from every ≈øteeple.
The King while they doe thus pre≈øume,
Unto this Realme that right ≈øhall doome,
He ≈øhall this Kingdome wi≈øely guide,
And other Kingdomes more be≈øide:
Then Peers and Commons ≈øhall elect,
Who≈øe Lawes ≈øhall ever take effect.
No man ≈øhall Lawyers coun≈øell crave,

And Officers each towne within,
Shall right their wrongs and puni≈øh ≈øin;
Worthies be nine, and reckon me,
And this the tenth and la≈øt ≈øhall be:
The Moone ob≈øeur'd full ≈øixty yeare,
Shall then get light, and ≈øhine full cleare ‚Ä¢

That have been neither hot nor cold.

Untill ≈øhe truely her ≈øelfe reforme:
Such hurly burly, and ≈øuch ≈øtir,

div.head: Another.
div.l: ENgland thy proper native thee betrayes,
Becau≈øe all Nations hate thee and thy wayes,
Spaine doth undermine thee, France doth grow;
Wales threates, the Iri≈øh thee by ≈ønares doth awe
And thou thy ≈øelfe do≈øt wholy rain'd lye;

div.head: Another out of an ancient Manu≈øcript.
div.l: VVHen pride is in price,
And wit is in vice,
When Robbery as rife as Rye in the Rice;
When great men are Lawle≈ø≈øe,

Gods body and bloud not given the heeding,

But ≈øal Fortune turne her wheele?
When the yeere of our Lord is commen and gan,
One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forte and twain,
Then zeale ≈øal la≈øt for ever and aye
Til the Sonne of God take all away.
